Graphical abstract A sustainable aqueous potassium-ion battery was developed using manganese hexacyanoferrate and other cost-efficient materials, achieving high energy density and longevity enabled by Fe-doping, crystallinity improvement, and electrolyte optimization. To address challenges related to the intermittency of renewable energy sources, aqueous potassium-ion batteries (AKIBs) are a promising and sustainable alternative to conventional systems for large-scale energy storage. To enable their practical application, maximizing energy density and longevity while minimizing production and material costs is a key goal. In this work, we propose an AKIB consisting only of abundant and cost-efficient materials, which delivers a high energy density of more than 70 Wh kg−1. We combine simple strategies to stabilize the Mn-rich Prussian blue analog cathode by Fe-doping, improving the crystallinity, and tuning the electrolyte composition without employing expensive water-in-salt electrolytes. Using a mixed 2.5 M Ca(NO3)2 + 1.5 M KNO3 electrolyte, we assemble a novel AKIB with a Fe-doped manganese hexacyanoferrate cathode and an organic poly(naphthalene-4-formyl-ethylenediamine) anode. Besides a high energy density, the full cell delivers a specific capacity of approximately 60 mA h g−1, a power density of 5000 W kg−1, and 80% capacity retention after 600 cycles. Keywords Aqueous Battery Electrolyte Potassium Calcium 1 Introduction The rise in global energy demand, along with the global warming and environmental pollution caused by fossil fuel, necessitates the utilization of renewable energy sources, such as solar, wind, tidal, etc. Due to the intermittent nature of these energy sources, energy storage systems are needed to maximize their usage. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) dominate the markets of electric vehicles and consumer electronics owing to their high energy density and cycling stability [1,2]. However, LIBs are plagued by safety risks caused by flammable and toxic organic electrolytes and high costs due to the limited and uneven distribution of lithium in the earth’s crust [3,4]. Aqueous potassium-ion batteries (AKIBs) comprising non-flammable aqueous electrolytes and earth-abundant potassium emerged as a promising alternative. Further, potassium is an alkali metal with a standard redox potential of −2.936 V vs. SHE, comparable to that of lithium (−3.040 V vs. SHE) and lower than that of sodium (−2.714 V vs. SHE), enabling higher operating voltages and boosting the energy density [5]. Moreover, the weakest Lewis acidity of K+ compared to Li+ and Na+ results in the smallest Stokes radius, favoring higher ionic diffusion in aqueous electrolytes and rate capability [6]. However, the practical implementation of this battery system is hampered by an insufficient cycle life and narrow thermodynamic electrochemical stability window of water (1.23 V), suppressing the operating voltage, which limits the energy density [7–10]. Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) are a promising class of cathode materials for aqueous potassium-ion batteries, generally represented by the chemical formula A x MA[MB(CN)6] y □1− y ·zH2O, where A is a guest cation (Li, Na, K, Mg or Ca), MA is a transition metal such as Fe, Mn, Co, Ni or Cu, MB is commonly Fe, and □ denotes MB(CN)6 vacancy. The rigid 3D framework of PBAs with large interstitial sites can accommodate potassium ions, while open channels enable intercalation and deintercalation. Based on the electrochemical activity of the transition metal, the electrochemical mechanism can be divided into single-electron redox reactions represented by redox-inactive metals such as Ni, Cu, and Zn and multi-electron redox reactions represented by redox-active metals such as Fe, Mn, Co and V [10–14]. Typically, the PBAs relying on single-electron redox reactions such as K0.6Ni1.2Fe(CN)6·3.6H2O [15] or K0.71Cu[Fe(CN)6]0.72·3.7H2O [16] deliver low specific capacities of about 60 mA h g−1, but have a long cycle life (5000–40000 cycles). Comparing, K2Fe[Fe(CN)6]·2H2O [17] or K2Co[Fe(CN)6] [18] functioning through multi-electron redox reaction achieve above 100 mA h g−1, but show significantly faster capacity decay (∼500 cycles). A candidate holding great promise for AKIBs is K2Mn[Fe(CN)6], as it offers the highest theoretical capacity and operating voltage and incorporates low-cost and non-polluting elements [19,20]. Nevertheless, low cycle life induced by dissolution of Mn in aqueous electrolytes and structural instability due to Mn3+-triggered Jahn–Teller distortion are major setbacks for this material [14,21]. A significant breakthrough was achieved in a full AKIB comprising Fe-doped Mn-rich PBA (K x Fe y Mn1 − y [Fe(CN)6]w·zH2O) and 22 mol kg−1 (m) potassium trifluoromethane sulfonate (KCF3SO3) water-in-salt electrolyte, where the suppression of detrimental phase transition was attributed to Fe substitution. In contrast, a low amount of free water in the electrolyte alleviates Mn dissolution [22]. However, as noted by the authors, the high consumption of the expensive KCF3SO3 salt associated with this approach limits its practical applicability. An alternative strategy for Mn dissolution mitigation in organic electrolytes was accomplished in nearly stoichiometric K2Mn[Fe(CN)6] with a negligible amount of defects and water, synthesized with the aid of the chelating agent EDTA [21]. In our recent work, we demonstrated the use of concentrated Ca-based electrolytes as a more sustainable approach to limit PBA dissolution [23]. Herein, we introduce a full AKIB cell comprising a Fe-doped Mn-PBA cathode, a poly(naphthalene-4-formyl-ethylenediamine) (PNFE) anode, and an inexpensive 2.5 M Ca(NO3)2 + 1.5 M KNO3 electrolyte. The enhanced capacity retention of Mn-PBA was achieved by combined effects of Fe doping, regulating the crystal growth with the aid of a chelating agent, and introducing Ca-ions as an electrolyte additive. The optimized cathode and anode materials deliver high specific capacities of 109 and 150 mA h g−1, respectively, while combined in the full cell, 60 mA h g−1 specific capacity, an energy density above 70 Wh kg−1, and a maximum power density of approximately 5000 W kg−1 was obtained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of PNFE All chemicals for synthesis were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Poly(naphthalene-4-formyl-ethylenediamine) (PNFE) was synthesized in our previous work, and the anode active material used in this study originates from the same batch [24]. Initially, 10 mmol (2.68 g) of 1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxylic dianhydride (NTCDA) and 10 mmol (0.6 g) of ethylenediamine (EDA) were dissolved in 20 mL of degassed N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) in a Schlenk flask. The mixture was heated to 215 °C in a sand bath and refluxed overnight, causing the formation of a dark precipitate. The resulting product was filtered and thoroughly washed several times with NMP and water. Drying was performed under vacuum at 0.08 mbar in three sequential steps (room temperature, 120 and 210 °C). This process yielded a grey-brownish powder with a high yield of 92% (2.7 g). Elemental analysis of PNFE: Calcd. for an infinite polyimide (C16H8N2O4), %: C 65.76, H 2.76, N 9.59; calcd. for an octamer, %: C 65.10, H 3.03, N 10.52; found, %: C 65.13, H 2.91, N 10.32. 2.1.2 Synthesis of MnHCF and FeMnHCF Manganese hexacyanoferrate (MnHCF) and iron manganese hexacyanoferrate were synthesized via coprecipitation. In both cases, 200 mL of solution A, containing the transition metal salt(s), and 200 mL of solution B, containing 8 mmol of K3[Fe(CN)6] (Sigma Aldrich, USA), were simultaneously added dropwise into 100 mL of deionized (DI) water under continuous stirring at 60 °C. For MnHCF, solution A was prepared by dissolving 8 mmol MnSO4 (Sigma Aldrich, USA) in 200 mL DI water. For FeMnHCF-A, solution A contained a mixture of 1.4 mmol FeSO4 (Sigma Aldrich, USA) and 2.6 mmol MnSO4 (Sigma Aldrich, USA) dissolved in 200 mL of DI water. To produce morphology-controlled FeMnHCF-C, solution A was prepared by dissolving 2.8 mmol FeSO4, 5.2 mmol MnSO4, and 8 mmol C6H5Na3O7⋅2H2O (Sigma Aldrich, USA) in 200 mL DI water. 4 mmol of K4[Fe(CN)6] were dissolved in 200 mL of DI water to form solution B. Once the additions were complete, the respective mixtures were left to age overnight. Following the aging process, the products were separated by centrifugation, washed two times with water and once with ethanol, and dried overnight at 70 °C. 2.2 Electrode preparation PNFE, MnHCF, and FeMnHCF electrodes were prepared using the slurry-casting method. The PNFE slurry consisted of 80 wt. % polyimide active material, 10 wt. % carbon black super C-65 (MTI, USA) and 10 wt. % Nafion™ binder (5 wt. % in lower aliphatic alcohols and water, Sigma Aldrich, USA). These components were mixed and ground in a planetary ball mill, after which water and isopropyl alcohol in a 1:1 ratio were added as dispersing agents under vigorous stirring to form the anode slurry. Cathode slurries were prepared similarly by combining 80 wt. % active material (MnHCF or FeMnHCF), 10 wt. % carbon black super C-65 and 10 wt. % polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF, MTI, USA) in a planetary ball mill. NMP was added as a solvent to these cathode mixtures under vigorous stirring to produce homogeneous slurries. Final electrode production involved casting the prepared slurries onto pyrolytic graphite sheet current collectors. The active material mass loadings were approximately 2 mg cm−2 for the PNFE anode and 3 mg cm−2 for the MnHCF, FeMnHCF-A, and FeMnHCF-C cathodes. 2.3 Material characterization Morphological investigations of electrode films were conducted using a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Zeiss Gemini NVision40). In the case of FeMnHCF-C, the average particle size was determined from these SEM images by creating a particle size distribution using the software ImageJ. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted with a Rigaku MiniFlex 600-C X-ray diffractometer utilizing Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) and an integrated Ni-based filter to analyze the crystal structure and crystallinity of the MnHCF and FeMnHCF active material powders. For inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), MnHCF, FeMnHCF-A, and FeMnHCF-C were dissolved in 65% HNO3 and subsequently analyzed for their relative Mn and Fe contents. Nitrogen gas sorption isotherms were recorded with a Micrometrics 3Flex analyzer under liquid nitrogen at 77 K for surface area and pore size analysis. The BET-specific surface area and pore size distribution were evaluated using the dedicated software provided by Micrometrics 3Flex. The prepared electrodes and the bare substrate were cut into small pieces, filled into the measuring tubular glass cells, and activated at 120 ℃ for 16 h under vacuum before the analysis. Viscosity measurements were conducted on a commercial shear rheometer (MCR 302, Anton Paar GmbH, Graz, Austria) equipped with a cone-shaped measuring head (CP50-1, 79040, Anton Paar) and an air-cooled bottom plate (P-PTD 200/56/Air, Anton Paar). For each sample, the viscosity was measured over a shear rate range from 1000 to 5 s−1 following a logarithmic ramp. Five measuring points were captured within each decade, and three technical replicates of this measurement were conducted per sample type. All measurements were conducted at 25°C, and a solvent trap was used to prevent liquid evaporation from the samples during the measurements. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical investigations of individual electrodes were performed using a three-electrode setup in a closed glass cell under constant argon flow to maintain an inert atmosphere. Before introducing the electrolytes, both the glass cell and the electrolytes were purged with argon for at least 10 min. A platinum wire (MaTeck, Germany) served as the counter electrode, and the Ag/AgCl reference electrode (SSC, 3 M KCl, SI Analytics) was connected to the electrolyte via a Luggin capillary. The electrolytes employed in this study included 5 M Ca(NO3)2, 3 M KNO3, and a 1:1 (volume) mixture of the two, resulting in a solution containing 2.5 M Ca(NO3)2 and 1.5 M KNO3 (CKN2515). Electrochemical measurements were conducted with a BioLogic VSP-300 potentiostat. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic cycling with potential limitations (GCPL) were employed to evaluate the performance of the electrodes. Initial stability and intercalation investigations of the cathode materials in the three electrolytes were performed via CV at a scan rate of 20 mV s−1 with potentials ranging from 0 to 1.5 V vs. SSC. Further investigations of the FeMnHCF-C slurry cathode with the CKN2515 electrolyte involved CV measurements at scan rates ranging from 1 to 50 mV s−1 within the same potential range. Furthermore, GCPL measurements were conducted at C-rates ranging from 100 C to 1 C, within a potential range of 0 and 1.3 V vs. SSC. The PNFE slurry anode was characterized using similar methods, with CV conducted over a potential range of 0 to −0.9 V vs. SSC and GCPL measurements performed between 0 and −0.8 V vs. SSC. 2.5 Full-cell assembly and measurements A 3D-printed plastic cell with pyrolytic graphite foil contacts was used as the full-cell casing to prevent the corrosion of stainless steel contacts. An aqueous K/Ca-ion battery was assembled using the CKN2515 electrolyte, a FeMnHCF-C slurry cathode, and a PNFE slurry anode, with a cathode to anode active material mass ratio of 1:1.4. Assembly was conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere inside a glovebox to prevent oxygen dissolution in the electrolyte. An electrolyte-soaked commercial BS 17–25 separator (Mativ Inc., France), designed for alkaline batteries, was placed between the electrodes, and the cell was sealed with rubber O-rings. For the performance evaluation, GCPL was performed using a BioLogic VSP-300 potentiostat. The cell was cycled at C-rates ranging from 100 C to 1 C within a voltage range of 0 to 2.1 V. 3 Results and discussion The structural and morphological properties of the Mn-based PBAs were analyzed using XRD, ICP-MS, and SEM. Fig. 1 shows the results of the morphological investigation of MnHCF, FeMnHCF-A, and FeMnHCF-C via SEM. The fitted XRD patterns are displayed in Fig. S1. The XRD data of a Si reference were used for all three samples to estimate the instrumental resolution function. The XRD pattern of MnHCF exhibits narrow diffraction peaks and weak splitting with several weak reflections underneath the high-intensity ones. This indicates high-symmetry ordering. The diffraction intensities can be modeled by a parent cubic structure (Fm-3m, a = 10.504 Å) (left side of Fig. S1(a)) [25] while the symmetric splitting of reflections indicates a weak distortion, which can be modeled by a tetragonal lattice with doubled c lattice parameters (primitive, a = 10.530 Å, 20.991 Å) (right side of Fig. S1(a)). A small tetragonal distortion of 0.3% can be concluded. The SEM analysis (Fig. 1 (a)) of the MnHCF cathode reveals agglomerated, nonuniform particles of inconsistent size (up to ∼7 µm). As shown in Table S1, ICP-MS indicates a Fe/Mn ratio of merely 0.83. This small share can be attributed to a high number of Fe(CN)6 vacancies, which is consistent with the comparably low crystallinity revealed by the SEM and XRD analysis. The FeMnHCF-A XRD pattern (Fig. S1(b)) reveals a series of well-isolated, broad peaks, which (similar to MnHCF) can be indexed with a parent cubic lattice (Fm-3m, a = 10.188 Å), with the exception of two sharp reflections associated with an unidentified secondary phase. For this sample, no measurable tetragonal distortion can be concluded. Similar to MnHCF, the SEM images of the FeMnHCF-A slurry mainly feature irregularly shaped particles of ranging sizes (up to ∼3 µm), with the largest particles being smaller than those in the MnHCF sample. For both samples, generating a particle size distribution was not possible due to difficulties in distinguishing smaller particles. However, both samples exhibit a wide range of particle sizes and irregular shapes, suggesting low crystallinity. ICP-MS reveals a Fe/Mn ratio of 1.68 (Table S1 ) and, thus, a successful decrease in the density of Mn in the lattice. The structure of FeMnHCF-C can be unambiguously associated with the structural model of the KMnHCF-type [5], which is reflected by a characteristic triplet at ca. 2θ = 25°. The best fits (Fig. S1(c)) were obtained for space group P21/c, a = 6.983 Å, b = 7.304 Å, c = 12.305 Å, β = 124.79°. The sample is characterized by high crystallinity. The peak broadening analysis revealed a weak microstrain of isotropic character, which can be attributed to local chemical inhomogeneities affecting the peak widths at high scattering angles. The high crystallinity is backed up by the SEM (Fig. 1 (c)) analysis, showing crystalline, cube-like particles of consistent size. The size consistency and crystallinity are reflected by a narrow particle size distribution (Fig. S2), yielding an average particle size of about (858 ± 96) nm. Here, the largest particles are significantly smaller compared to those in the other samples. The more uniform and regular morphology of FeMnHCF-C can be attributed to the chelating effect of the sodium citrate additive during the synthesis. By binding to the transition metal cations, the citrate anions slow down the crystallization rate, effectively reducing the density of lattice defects [20,26]. ICP-MS reveals a Fe/Mn ratio of 1.37 (Table S1). FeMnHCF-C represents a highly crystalline sample with slightly lower Fe incorporation, resulting from the citrate-aided coprecipitation procedure. BET analysis was carried out to determine the specific surface area and pore size distribution of all three samples. The nitrogen sorption isotherms (Fig. S3(a)) indicate a drastic decrease in overall porosity in iron-doped samples. MnHCF exhibited a type-I isotherm with a calculated specific surface area (SSA) of 81 m2 g−1 compared to MnFeHCF-A and MnFeHCF-C, which demonstrated 5.6 and 2 m2 g−1, respectively. Under identical measurement conditions, the graphite substrate showed a negligible SSA of 0.5 m2 g−1. It is worth mentioning that MnFeHCF-A has a larger hysteresis between relative pressures (P/P 0) of 0.4 and 0.8 with a type-IV isotherm, indicating the presence of mesopores. The NLDFT pore size distribution (Fig. S3(b)) confirms the presence of micropores of 0.9 and 1.1 nm (<2 nm) in the MnHCF sample, whereas in the samples MnFeHCF-A and MnFeHCF-C a lower amount of broadly distributed mesopores between 6–20 nm can be observed. This indicates that the large MnHCF agglomerates observed in the SEM pictures are, in fact, porous structures with small micropores instead of regular crystals, which can be attributed to the high defect content. In contrast, the FeMnHCF-A and, particularly, the FeMnHCF-C samples consist of more evenly distributed crystalline particles, as the SEM and XRD measurements showed before. Hence, they only feature larger mesopores and, thus, a lower specific surface area. Fig. 2 shows the 1st, 10th, and 50th CV cycles and the capacity retention per cycle over 100 cycles of MnHCF, FeMnHCF-A, and FeMnHCF-C in different electrolytes. Due to a short precycling phase linked to slow electrode wetting, which was observed in all electrodes, the “1st cycle” refers to the cycle at which the peak currents reached their maximum, and no further growth was observed. In saturated 3 M KNO3, pure MnHCF displays a dominant pair of oxidation and reduction peaks at 0.73 V and 0.55 V vs. SSC, respectively, corresponding to the FeII/III transition (Fig. 2 (a)). The additional MnII/III transition is represented by another pair of peaks at 1.28 V and 0.91 V vs. SSC. The steep increase in current toward the right potential boundary is associated with the parasitic oxygen evolution side reactions, indicating that the electrode can only be reversibly cycled to potentials below ∼1.30 V vs. SSC. To monitor the cycling stability, the electrode was repeatedly reduced and oxidized for 100 cycles at 20 mV s−1 (Fig. 2 (a) and (j)). By comparing the 1st and 10th cycles, it becomes apparent that MnHCF experiences rapid degradation in this electrolyte. Previous studies have shown that Mn-based PBAs suffer severe structural changes due to Jahn-Teller distortions at the N-coordinated Mn centers [20,27]. According to the literature, MnHCF undergoes a partly irreversible phase transition from cubic to tetragonal during the MnII/III redox process, which is related to structural collapse and capacity loss [28,29]. Hence, material or electrolyte modifications are necessary to enhance the cycle life of MnHCF and enable its practical application. Doping with different transition metal ions such as Fe, Ni, or Co has been identified as an effective strategy to mitigate the detrimental effects of Jahn-Teller distortions by decreasing the Mn density in the crystal lattice [22,30,31]. In addition, this substitution has been shown to significantly change the MnII/III redox mechanism, further impeding phase transitions [32]. A detailed investigation of this effect was previously reported by Jiang et al. in 2019. They showed that, while pure MnHCF undergoes two phase transitions from monoclinic to cubic and cubic to tetragonal, iron doping introduces a solid solution reaction with a single-phase transition between monoclinic and cubic with higher reversibility. Furthermore, the MnII/III and the FeII/III redox processes are completely independent in MnHCF. In contrast, the Fe-doped FeMnHCF exhibits activity of the FeII/III redox couple over the full potential range. In addition, they showed that due to the Fe-doping, the MnII/III redox reaction becomes asymmetric, significantly altering the mechanism and suppressing Jahn-Teller distortions [22]. Other groups have also reported similar results investigating the effects of Ni, Co, and Fe doping on Mn-based PBAs [30,32,33]. Accordingly, the iron-doped FeMnHCF-A shows significantly improved cycling stability, as shown in Fig. 2 (b) and (j). In addition, this modification shifts the left pair of peaks toward more negative potentials, whereas the more positive redox peaks become more pronounced, enabling a higher capacity utilization at high potentials. The CV curve of MnHCF-C features only one major oxidation and reduction peak, at 1.05 V and 0.77 V vs. SSC, respectively, showing that the electrochemical behavior of the Mn-based PBA is influenced both by the crystallinity and the composition (Fig. 2(c)). Although both FeMnHCF-A and FeMnHCF-C display significant stability improvements compared to pure MnHCF, they still suffer from severe electrode degradation and capacity loss in KNO3, as demonstrated in Fig. 2 (j). Typically, this can be addressed by utilizing highly concentrated water-in-salt electrolytes based on highly soluble fluorinated salts such as KCF3SO3 or potassium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (KFSI) [34,35]. However, as mentioned above, this strategy is associated with high electrolyte costs as it requires high amounts of expensive salts. In our previous work, we have demonstrated the use of a low-cost saturated CaCl2 electrolyte as an alternative approach to stabilize a Cu-based PBA cathode [23]. Since the divalent Ca-ions have a much higher charge density and more negative hydration energy than the monovalent K-ions, they can bind more water molecules in their hydration shell [36]. Additionally, at the same molarity, the anion concentration is doubled compared to the equivalent potassium salt, further reducing the amount of free water. As for water-in-salt electrolytes, this mitigates harmful side reactions and active material dissolution. Furthermore, the strong interaction of Ca2+ with OH− can suppress the detrimental effect of the well-studied alkaline degradation pathway of PBAs, similar to what has been observed in mildly acidic electrolytes [37]. In this work, saturated Ca(NO3)2, corresponding to a concentration of 5 M, was used instead of CaCl2 to avoid the oxidation of Cl− at the relatively high potentials needed to charge Mn-based PBAs. As shown in Fig. 2 (d–f), all three electrodes exhibit significantly lower capacity fading in this electrolyte. Especially the CV curves of FeMnHCF-C display almost no changes within 50 cycles, demonstrating the successful stabilization of the electrode. Fig. 2 (k) shows that FeMnHCF-C retains nearly 100% of its maximum capacity after 100 cycles. It should be noted that besides the limited free water content, 5 M Ca(NO3)2 is also characterized by a higher viscosity than 3 M KNO3, as shown in Fig. S4. This hinders the transport of dissolution products away from the electrode surface and further impedes degradation. Previous research shows that confining the dissolved transition metal ions in close vicinity of the electrode can trigger ultrafast nucleation and restructuring of the PBA in the presence of Fe(CN)6-anions [38]. Similar to the mechanism driving the electrochemical deposition of PBAs used to synthesize thin films, the active material can regrow on the electrode when the dissolution products remain close to the electrode [39]. Hence, the sluggish diffusion of dissolved transition metal ions in the bulk electrolyte has been linked to highly improved PBA cycling stability [40]. While this approach effectively enhances the long-term performance of all investigated Mn-based PBAs, it also significantly alters their reduction and oxidation potentials. For all three electrodes, the peaks are shifted in the negative direction and display an increased peak-to-peak separation, indicating lower reversibility of the redox reaction. Both effects can be considered disadvantageous, as they are detrimental to the efficiency, cell voltage, and hence energy density of the full cell. Therefore, to combine the stabilizing influence of Ca2+ and the favorable (de-)intercalation potentials of the PBAs in the presence of K+, a mixed 2.5 M Ca(NO3)2 + 1.5 M KNO3 electrolyte, denoted as CKN2515, was prepared. This approach takes advantage of the relatively high co-solubility of Ca(NO3)2 and KNO3, allowing the mixing of the two saturated solutions without the crystallization of either salt. While the resulting mixture features a lower viscosity than 5 M Ca(NO3)2, its viscosity is about 4 times higher than for 3 M KNO3 (Fig. S4). The cycling performances of MnHCF, FeMnHCF-A, and FeMnHCF-C in CKN2515 are shown in Fig. 2 (g–i), respectively. The capacity retention over 100 cycles is shown in Fig. 2 (l). In the CV of MnHCF, the peaks corresponding to Ca2+ (de-)intercalation can be observed in the first few cycles but vanish quickly. Afterward, the reduction peak shifts to the right, resulting in a CV shape similar to that of pure KNO3, indicating that the intercalation of K-ions is preferred over Ca-ions. While MnHCF still degrades severely, FeMnHCF-A and FeMnHCF-C display significant stability improvements, similar to 5 M Ca(NO3)2, with FeMnHCF-C being the most stable. Furthermore, the redox peak positions and shapes of the iron-doped PBAs in CKN2515 are the same as in pure KNO3, showing that Ca2+ only takes a passive role in the electrolyte and is not intercalated into the crystal lattice. Hence, the mixed electrolyte preserves the stabilizing effect of the Ca-based electrolyte, as well as the advantageous redox potential and reversibility of the cathode in the K-based electrolyte. In summary, the cyclability of Mn-based PBAs was largely improved by combining Mn-substitution, the use of a chelating agent during synthesis for controlled crystallinity, and electrolyte composition tuning. To investigate the electrochemical performance of the optimized FeMnHCF-C cathode in CKN2515, galvanostatic cycling was carried out at different C-rates ranging from 1 C to 100 C. The potential range was set to 0.0–1.3 V vs. SSC since parasitic OER currents were observed in the CVs at potentials above 1.3 V vs. SSC. The resulting charge and discharge curves are shown in Fig. 3 (a). At 1 C, the discharge profile displays a sloping plateau between 0.95 and 0.60 V vs. SSC and a reversible specific capacity of ∼109 mA h g−1 at a coulombic efficiency of ∼92%. The FeMnHCF-C electrode also exhibits excellent fast-charging capabilities, retaining ∼91% of the discharge capacity from 1 C to 10 C. Moreover, it displays exceptional performance even at high rates (30 C–100 C) with a specific discharge capacity of ∼60 mA h g−1 at 100 C and nearly 100% efficiency at all rates above 10 C. Fig. 3 (b) shows the CV curves of FeMnHCF-C recorded at different scan rates ranging from 1 to 50 mV s−1. The peak-to-peak separation between the dominant oxidation peak and the two main reduction peaks increases with increasing scan rate due to the uncompensated resistance linked to the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. However, at 1 mV s−1, it drops to ∼20 and ∼120 mV for the left and right peaks, respectively, indicating that the intercalation of K+ into the PBA structure is highly reversible. Moreover, it is possible to deduce information about the process limiting the charge transfer by relating the peak current j p to the scan rate ν (1) j p = b · ν a For surface-limited processes, parameter a approaches 1.0, while for mass-transport-limited processes it approaches 0.5. As shown in the inset in Fig. 3 (b), a is close to 0.56 (evaluated for the main oxidation peak), indicating that the charge transfer is mostly mass-transport limited, as expected for slurry electrodes of intercalation-type materials. To maintain the superior performance of the FeMnHCF-C cathode in a full cell setup, an anode with equally high specific capacity, stability, and fast charging capabilities is required. Here, the organic redox-active material PNFE was employed as the anode, as it was previously shown to deliver extremely high-rate capabilities and exceptional cyclability [23,24,41,42]. PNFE was synthesized in a one-step dehydration condensation reaction between NTCDA and EDA in NMP, and the structure was confirmed by FTIR (Fig. S5(b)). An SEM image of the anode consisting of PNFE particles, typically between 100 and 500 nm in size, carbon black, and the Nafion binder is shown in Fig. S5(a). The electrochemical performance of the anode in the CKN2515 aqueous electrolyte was investigated by galvanostatic cycling and cyclic voltammetry. Fig. 4 (a) shows the charge and discharge profiles recorded at different C-rates ranging from 1 C to 100 C. At 1 C, PNFE displays a reversible specific capacity of ∼150 mA h g−1, maintaining ca. 93% at 10 C. Moreover, it shows an exceptional high-rate capability with ca. 66% capacity retention even at 100 C, closely matching the fast-charging capabilities of the cathode. Fig. 4 (b) shows the CV curves of the anode recorded at different scan rates ranging from 1 to 50 mV s−1. As shown in our previous work, PNFE undergoes a two-step redox process, corresponding to the subsequent enolization of two carbonyl groups [24]. This general mechanism remains unchanged regardless of whether monovalent or divalent cations are inserted [23]. In the anodic scan, this is reflected by two distinct oxidation peaks, whereas the reduction peaks overlap in the cathodic scan. It is worth noting that at the PNFE anode, the oxidation and reduction of the active material are compensated by Ca-ions rather than K-ions in the mixed CKN2515 electrolyte, which can easily be seen by comparing the peak shape and positions of the measurement conducted in CKN2515 with the CVs of PNFE recorded in 3 M KNO3 and 5 M Ca(NO3)2 depicted in Fig. S5(c) and (d), respectively. By relating the peak current of the main reduction peak with the scan rate via equation (1), parameter a is found to be close to 0.9, indicating that for the anode, the charge transfer process is mainly surface-limited. These minimal diffusion limitations can be linked to the pseudo-capacitive charge storage mechanism of the polyimide [24,41,42]. Based on the promising performance of both the FeMnHCF-C cathode and the PNFE anode in the CKN2515 aqueous electrolyte, a PNFE/CKN2515/FeMnHCF-C full cell was assembled, with an anode to cathode active material mass ratio of 1:1.4. Fig. 5 (a) shows the (dis-)charge profiles of the full battery recorded at different C-rates between 1 C (62 mA g−1) and 100 C (6.2 A g−1). The corresponding data can be found in Table S2. Within the voltage window from 0.0 to 1.9 V at 1 C, the battery exhibits a reversible capacity of ∼62 mA h g−1 and a sloping discharge plateau between 1.8 and 1.0 V. It also shows superior fast charging capabilities with ∼85% capacity retention at 10 C and ∼25% capacity retention at high rates of up to 100 C. The coulombic efficiency increases from ∼94% at 1 C to above 99% at higher rates, confirming that the CKN2515 aqueous electrolyte is electrochemically stable within the operating voltage window of the battery. The cycling stability of the full cell was assessed by continuously charging and discharging it at 10 C for 600 cycles. As shown in Fig. 5(b and c), the battery retains ∼80% of its maximum specific discharge capacity, which is reached after ca. 50 cycles due to the slow penetration of the electrolyte into the pores of the slurry electrodes. The corresponding energy and power densities for each C-rate can be calculated by integrating the discharge curves and by multiplying the specific current with the average discharge voltage, respectively. At a power density of ca. 70 W kg−1, the battery displays a high energy density of 72 Wh kg−1, of which 12 Wh kg−1 can be retained even at extremely high power densities of up to ∼5000 W kg−1. These performance parameters are compared to state-of-the-art AKIBs reported in recent literature in Fig. 5 (d). Most notably, Jiang et al. achieved a slightly higher energy density of 80 Wh kg−1 with an aqueous battery based on a FeMnHCF cathode and an organic 3,4,9,10-perylene tetracarboxylic diimide (PTCDI) anode [22]. Similar high energy densities were also reported by Liang et al. in 2021 using the same anode material and a KVO x cathode [44]. Furthermore, the designs proposed by Wang et al., Li et al., and Chen et al. are worth mentioning due to their competitive performances [34,35,43]. However, it should be noted that except for the PNFE/sat. KNO3/FeHCF aqueous battery reported by Wang et al., all other compositions rely on highly concentrated electrolytes based on relatively expensive salts, such as 22 m KCF3SO3 or 30 m KFSI. While these water-in-salt electrolytes generally enable even longer cycle lives than the one shown in this work, their use is linked to largely increased material costs compared to the proposed CKN2515 electrolyte, which consists of abundant and available materials. As rightfully mentioned by Jiang et al., the economic viability of AKIBs will require employing lower-concentration electrolytes based on more cost-efficient salts [22]. Hence, modifying the FeMnHCF-C synthesis, combined with the Ca(NO3)2 electrolyte additive and the highly stable PNFE anode, can be a step toward the practical application of AKIBs for energy storage. 4 Conclusions In this study, we have developed a sustainable, high-performance aqueous potassium-ion battery (AKIB) utilizing a Fe-doped FeMn[Fe(CN)6] cathode, an organic PNFE anode, and a mixed KNO3 + Ca(NO3)2 electrolyte. Through a series of strategic modifications, we significantly enhanced the cycle life of the Mn-based Prussian blue analog (PBA) cathode. Specifically, we investigated the synergistic effects of Fe doping, controlled crystal growth facilitated by chelating agents, and the incorporation of Ca-ions as an electrolyte additive. The optimized cathode demonstrates a high specific capacity of approximately 109 mA h g−1 and excellent capacity retention even at rapid charging rates of up to 100 C. Complementing this, the PNFE anode achieves a notable specific capacity of around 150 mA h g−1 and exceptional high-rate performance. Combined, the PNFE/CKN2515/FeMnHCF-C full cell achieves a reversible specific capacity of ∼60 mA h g−1, an energy density exceeding 70 Wh kg−1, and a maximum power density of approximately 5000 W kg−1, based on the active materials in the anode and cathode. Remarkably, this battery delivers competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art AKIBs that utilize more expensive and less sustainable water-in-salt electrolytes like KCF3SO3 or KFSI. These results underscore the potential of this cost-effective and environmentally friendly system to advance the development of sustainable energy storage technologies. coredata.dc:description: To address challenges related to the intermittency of renewable energy sources, aqueous potassium-ion batteries (AKIBs) are a promising and sustainable alternative to conventional systems for large-scale energy storage. To enable their practical application, maximizing energy density and longevity while minimizing production and material costs is a key goal. In this work, we propose an AKIB consisting only of abundant and cost-efficient materials, which delivers a high energy density of more than 70 Wh kg−1. We combine simple strategies to stabilize the Mn-rich Prussian blue analog cathode by Fe-doping, improving the crystallinity, and tuning the electrolyte composition without employing expensive water-in-salt electrolytes. Using a mixed 2.5 M Ca(NO3)2 + 1.5 M KNO3 electrolyte, we assemble a novel AKIB with a Fe-doped manganese hexacyanoferrate cathode and an organic poly(naphthalene-4-formyl-ethylenediamine) anode. Besides a high energy density, the full cell delivers a specific capacity of approximately 60 mA h g−1, a power density of 5000 W kg−1, and 80% capacity retention after 600 cycles.

coredata.dc:title: A low-cost and high-energy aqueous potassium-ion battery
